citation.article-title: Taxonomic study of aromatic-degrading bacteria from deep-terrestrial-subsurface sediments and description of Sphingomonas aromaticivorans sp. nov., Sphingomonas subterranea sp. nov., and Sphingomonas stygia sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Sphinogomonas stygia sp. nov.
Sphinogomonas stygia (sty'gi.a. L. masc. n. Styx, underworld river in classical Greek mythology. L. adj. stygius, -a, pertaining to the underworld, subterranean)
Sphinogomonas stygia is a gram-negative, nonsporing, nonmotile, rod-shaped organism.
Colonies are circular, entire, low convex, smooth, opaque, and yellow.
Indole, urease, arid arginine dihydrolase are not produced.
Gelatin is not liquified, and glucose is not fermented.
Esculin and L-arabinose are assimilated aerobically, but adipate, D-gluconate, and L-malate are not assimilated aerobically.
Acid is produced oxidatively from L-arabinose, glucose, maltose, and sucrose, but not from D- or L-arabitol, dulcitol, L-fucose, galactose, inulin, mannitol, sorbitol, trehalose, or D-xylose.
The G+C content of the DNA is 65.4 mol%.
The major isoprenoid quinone is ubiquinone Q-10.
The major nonpolar fatty acids are 18:1ω7c, 16:1ω7c, 18:1ω5c, 14:0, and 16:0, and the major 2-hydroxy fatty acids are 2OH14:0, 18:0/2OH16:1, 18:1/2OH16:1, and 2OH15:0.
Source: isolated from saturated Atlantic coastal plain terrestrial subsurface sediments.
The type strain is B0712(=SMCC B0712).
